prompt.p: A 46-year-old woman is admitted to hospital with episodes of headaches, sweatiness and dizziness. On examination you find a mass in the abdomen and a meta-iodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scan confirms the diagnosis of phaeochromocytoma. Four hours later she reports another episode of a similar feeling. Her blood pressure (BP) is 210/105 mmHg.
What should be the immediate management in this situation?

modalFeedback.p: Optio n B (Phentolamine) is Correct. 2–5 mg IV; repeat until safe BP. Labetalol can be used as an alternative.
Option A (Metadrenaline test) is Incorrect. The diagnosis of phaeochromocytoma has already been established; controls need to be made for the blood pressure.
Option C (Surgery) is Incorrect. Often done electively after 4–5 weeks.
Option D (Thiazides) is Incorrect. This would take too long to stabilize the dangerously high blood pressures.
Option E (Watchful waiting) is Incorrect. This is a hypertensive emergency and emergency treatment should be given.
